PREFACE

Tits catalogue was planned by the late lamented Pandit Mahadeva Sh:
and bas been seen throngh the press by Dr. Kunhan Raja, M.A,, D. Phil,

This is the work of scholars, and an Officiating Director of the Library, ।
is only carrying on the work between the unfortunate demise of one
and the necessarily delayed appointment of another, cannot in propriety

much to say about it, I only sign it to give the book किल authority.
“He P. K. TELANG, `
वि Officiating


FOREWORD

We are placing before the public the first part of the Catalogue of the
Manuscripts in the Adyar Library. This part contains what may be called
Religious Literature (Veda, Purana, etc.) The second part will contain,
Secular Literature (Kavya, Alankara, Philosophy, ete.), ‘The Catalogue was
prepared under the supervision of the late lamented Director Pandit A, Maha-
deva Shastri, and the first’160 pages had already been printed off in his life-
time. We are issuing this patt of the Catalogue exactly as he had designed
and prepared it. The second part will be issued soon.
After the publication of the Catalogue by Dr. ए. 0. Schrader in 1910,

our collection has nearly doubled itself, and a new Catalogue has been long a
desideratum. In the 1910 Catalogue there were méntioned 11,842 MSS,
distributed under 5,270 titles. The present Catalogue, whiéh-refers to only ae
about half of our collection, mentions 9,442 manuscripts distributed under a
4,010 titles. The sub-joined table will show the increase under particular
headings.
The total collection of manuscripts in the Library numbers about 20,000,

An examination of the Catalogue will show that our Library has one of the 3

best collections of Indian manuscripts, especially South Indian naturally. As

the collection of manuscripts has extended over 40 years and as no detailed

descriptive Catalogue, besides the one relating to Upanishad MSS, edited by

Dr. 7. 0. Schrader in 1908, has np till now carefully been prepared, there

have crept some unayoidable mistakes into the cataloguing. The same work,

known under different names in different parts, is sometimes catalogued under

separate headings, Such mistakes could be corrected only when # careful
"descriptive catalogue is prepared after due examination of every manuscript. v

‘The present Catalogue must, from this pomt of view, be regarded merely as a ^

provisional list of manuscripts in the Library, We will try in time to issue

+ detailed descriptive list of at least the rare manuscripts which are of yalue

help to scholars, 4

र >

|

vi

The manuscripts are, as we have said, largely South Indian, written
on palm leaves in Tamil Grantha script or Telugu script mostly. There are a
number of manuscripts written in Canarese and Malayalam scripts too,
and some written in Bengali, Uria and Devanagari characters. There are q
few manuscripts in the Sarada, Nadyanagari and Roman scripts. There are
also # number of manuscripts written on indigenously manufactured
paper iv the Devanagari character, collected in North India, Our copyists
have made copies of many manuscripts from other Libraries, especially
from the Government Oriental MSS. Library, Madras. Many of the
manuscripts, specially the palm leaf ones, were very old and were in a
dilapidated condition, when they came to us, But after they eame into
our possession, we have taken all ‘possible care to preserve them, and we
are trying to take transcripts of them, so that‘even if these are worn out in
course of time, a faithful record of them may remain.

The Catalogue is arranged on, the following plan. It contains the
name of the work, (and within’ brackets any other name of the work, or
the name of the original cémplete work, if it isa part of any such), and the
name of the author? The shelf-number of the MS. is then mentioned, (the

first number is that of the shelf, the Roman letters show the row, and
the next number shows the number of the manuscript). The Devanagari
letter after that shows the seript in which the manuscript i¢ written and the
number following is the number of pages in the manuscript, Other useful
information is then given after that. a means that the manuscript ig
samt (incomplete). Many manuscripts after which this direction has
"inadvertently been omitted, are nevertheless incomplete.

A list of manuscripts collected after the preparation of this catalogue
ig given at the end. An Index containing an alphabetical list of authors and
smother contsining an alphabetical list of all the works, which are not yet
q d will be issued along with the second part of the catalogue, }

C. KUNHAN र
